name: Ready to try?

ops.insert:
Thank you for reading. I hope you enjoyed this reading this collection as much as I enjoyed creating it. Lewis Carroll gave us such a fantastic story to play with and building this collection was so much fun. With the help of computers I was able to create illustrations for many of the slides and I included some of my favorites. 

As you navigate the collection you may notice themes:
Pieces styled after historically dead artists.
Art that makes you tilt your head sideways.
When you copy an existing piece, you have a model to follow.
This makes it easier to get started because you know what you're supposed to do.
Seeing a finished project makes it easier to find inspiration of your own.
Instead of starting with a blank slate, fork this project and make it better.
Maybe your art could inspire someone else just like this inspired you!
Add funny pictures, change words, and create your own copy to share. Just like a coloring book.

contentHTML:
Ready to try?

Thank you for reading. I hope you enjoyed this reading this collection as much as I enjoyed creating it. Lewis Carroll gave us such a fantastic story to play with and building this collection was so much fun. With the help of computers I was able to create illustrations for many of the slides and I included some of my favorites.

As you navigate the collection you may notice themes:

  • Pieces styled after historically dead artists.
  • Backgrounds and border colors.
  • Some have big fonts.
  • Some have small fonts.
  • Lies
  • Art that makes you tilt your head sideways.


Copy this project

  • When you copy an existing piece, you have a model to follow.
  • This makes it easier to get started because you know what you're supposed to do.
  • Seeing a finished project makes it easier to find inspiration of your own.
  • Instead of starting with a blank slate, fork this project and make it better.
  • Share your project.
  • Maybe your art could inspire someone else just like this inspired you!


Add funny pictures, change words, and create your own copy to share. Just like a coloring book.
contentMarkdown:
## Ready to try?
Thank you for reading. I hope you enjoyed this reading this collection as much as I enjoyed creating it. Lewis Carroll gave us such a fantastic story to play with and building this collection was so much fun. With the help of computers I was able to create illustrations for many of the slides and I included some of my favorites. 

As you navigate the collection you may notice themes:
- Pieces styled after historically dead artists.  
- Backgrounds and border colors.
- Some have big fonts.
- Some have small fonts.
- Lies
- Art that makes you tilt your head sideways.


**Copy this project**
- When you copy an existing piece, you have a model to follow.
- This makes it easier to get started because you know what you're supposed to do.
- Seeing a finished project makes it easier to find inspiration of your own.
- Instead of starting with a blank slate, fork this project and make it better.
- Share your project.
- Maybe your art could inspire someone else just like this inspired you!


Add funny pictures, change words, and create your own copy to share. Just like a coloring book.

contentHTML:
About 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'

The Book

Alice's Adventures in Wonderland (commonly Alice in Wonderland) is an 1865 English novel by Lewis Carroll. A young girl named Alice falls through a rabbit hole into a fantasy world of anthropomorphic creatures. It is seen as an example of the literary nonsense genre.

One of the best-known works of Victorian literature, its narrative, structure, characters and imagery have had huge influence on popular culture and literature, especially in the fantasy genre. The book has never been out of print and has been translated into 174 languages. Its legacy covers adaptations for screen, radio, art, ballet, opera, musicals, theme parks, board games and video games. Carroll published a sequel in 1871 entitled Through the Looking-Glass and a shortened version for young children, The Nursery "Alice", in 1890.

Description from Wikipedia.

The Artist

Hello my name is Patrick Toner. I'm an open source software developer, an artist, a reader, and a fan of smart contracts.

I believe sharing will help us create the best art.

I believe sharing will make you happy.

Thank you for reading.
contentMarkdown:
# About '**Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'**
## The Book
**Alice's Adventures in Wonderland** (commonly **Alice in Wonderland**) is an 1865 English novel by Lewis Carroll. A young girl named Alice falls through a rabbit hole into a fantasy world of anthropomorphic creatures. It is seen as an example of the literary nonsense genre.

One of the best-known works of Victorian literature, its narrative, structure, characters and imagery have had huge influence on popular culture and literature, especially in the fantasy genre. The book has never been out of print and has been translated into 174 languages. Its legacy covers adaptations for screen, radio, art, ballet, opera, musicals, theme parks, board games and video games. Carroll published a sequel in 1871 entitled **Through the Looking-Glass** and a shortened version for young children, **The Nursery "Alice"**, in 1890. 

Description from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice's_Adventures_in_Wonderland).

## **The Artist**
Hello my name is Patrick Toner. I'm an open source software developer, an artist, a reader, and a fan of smart contracts. 

I believe sharing will help us create the best art. 

I believe sharing will make you happy. 

Thank you for reading.

name: FAQ

ops.insert: An NFT is a digital collectible. It's fun to collect things and NFTs allow us to collect digital items that inherit the permissionless and P2P nature of the Ethereum network. It's a big worldwide database that keeps track of the biggest fan of each piece. Just like a physical painting there can be many copies but some will just always be a little more special than others.
Why would I want to collect NFTs?

For the reasons your grandma has a closet full of your elementary school artwork. Collectibles help us remember. 

Collecting an NFT creates an entry in a database but more important it creates an entry in your mind. Every time you see your NFT you'll remember the moment you collected it. You'll remember all the context around that moment. Where you were. Who you were with. How the air smelled. It brings you back. It's like a magic trick.
Why use a Creative Commons Public Domain license?

enables scientists, educators, artists and other creators and owners of copyright- or database-protected content to waive those interests in their works and thereby place them as completely as possible in the public domain, so that others may freely build upon, enhance and reuse the works for any purposes without restriction under copyright or database law.

There are no legal rights associated with NFT ownership and all source code is MIT Licensed. Just because an NFT displays certain information doesn't mean you own that information. That would be silly.

I'm not sure even sure own is the right word. When you own an NFT that means your Ethereum account is mapped to a particular token ID in a smart contract. This mapping gives your wallet permission to transfer the NFT to another wallet. This basic utility allows you to list the NFT on many marketplaces.

But then again what does owning something even mean? If you can't trade it you don't own it. And you can trade your NFTs.

contentHTML:
FAQ

What are NFTs?

An NFT is a digital collectible. It's fun to collect things and NFTs allow us to collect digital items that inherit the permissionless and P2P nature of the Ethereum network. It's a big worldwide database that keeps track of the biggest fan of each piece. Just like a physical painting there can be many copies but some will just always be a little more special than others.

Why would I want to collect NFTs?

For the reasons your grandma has a closet full of your elementary school artwork. Collectibles help us remember.

Collecting an NFT creates an entry in a database but more important it creates an entry in your mind. Every time you see your NFT you'll remember the moment you collected it. You'll remember all the context around that moment. Where you were. Who you were with. How the air smelled. It brings you back. It's like a magic trick.

Why use a Creative Commons Public Domain license?

Creative Commons CC0 enables scientists, educators, artists and other creators and owners of copyright- or database-protected content to waive those interests in their works and thereby place them as completely as possible in the public domain, so that others may freely build upon, enhance and reuse the works for any purposes without restriction under copyright or database law.

There are no legal rights associated with NFT ownership and all source code is MIT Licensed. Just because an NFT displays certain information doesn't mean you own that information. That would be silly.

What do I actually own?

I'm not sure even sure own is the right word. When you own an NFT that means your Ethereum account is mapped to a particular token ID in a smart contract. This mapping gives your wallet permission to transfer the NFT to another wallet. This basic utility allows you to list the NFT on many marketplaces.

But then again what does owning something even mean? If you can't trade it you don't own it. And you can trade your NFTs.
contentMarkdown:
# FAQ
## **What are NFTs?**
An NFT is a digital collectible. It's fun to collect things and NFTs allow us to collect digital items that inherit the permissionless and P2P nature of the Ethereum network. It's a big worldwide database that keeps track of the biggest fan of each piece. Just like a physical painting there can be many copies but some will just always be a little more special than others. 

## **Why would I want to collect NFTs?**
For the reasons your grandma has a closet full of your elementary school artwork. Collectibles help us remember. 

Collecting an NFT creates an entry in a database but more important it creates an entry in your mind. Every time you see your NFT you'll remember the moment you collected it. You'll remember all the context around that moment. Where you were. Who you were with. How the air smelled. It brings you back. It's like a magic trick.

## **Why use a Creative Commons Public Domain license?**
[Creative Commons CC0](https://creativecommons.org/share-your-work/public-domain/cc0/) enables scientists, educators, artists and other creators and owners of copyright- or database-protected content to waive those interests in their works and thereby place them as completely as possible in the public domain, so that others may freely build upon, enhance and reuse the works for any purposes without restriction under copyright or database law.

There are no legal rights associated with NFT ownership and all source code is MIT Licensed. Just because an NFT displays certain information doesn't mean you own that information. That would be silly.

## **What do I actually own?**
I'm not sure even sure own is the right word. When you own an NFT that means your Ethereum account is mapped to a particular token ID in a smart contract. This mapping gives your wallet permission to transfer the NFT to another wallet. This basic utility allows you to list the NFT on many marketplaces.

But then again what does owning something even mean? If you can't trade it you don't own it. And you can trade your NFTs.
##
